body:
Looks like a standard disk corruption... 
Since everything gets validated, Bitcoin Core is very good in spotting all sorts of corruption on lower levels.

> Looks like a standard disk corruption...

After that crash, I tried to restart bitcoin-qt, it launched successfully, without any complain. The S.M.A.R.T data didn't report anything wrong, either.

When I was trying to copy them to the browser, I found that the GBK-encoded Chinese character string "Ã¨Â¿ÂÃ§Â¨ÂÃ¤Â¸Â»Ã¦ÂÂºÃ¥Â¼ÂºÃ¨Â¿Â«Ã¥ÂÂ³Ã©ÂÂ­Ã¤ÂºÂÃ¤Â¸ÂÃ¤Â¸ÂªÃ§ÂÂ°Ã¦ÂÂÃ§ÂÂÃ¨Â¿ÂÃ¦ÂÂ¥Ã£ÂÂ"(The remote host has forcibly closed an existing connection.) turned into a glitch.
